title: HILARIO T. DE LOS SANTOS, PETITIONER, VS. COURT OF APPEALS, EMILIO MILLER, SR., ROSEMARIE OLAZO, AND MANUEL SERRANA, JR., RESPONDENTS. D E C I S I O N MENDOZA, J.: Petitioner Hilario T. del los Santos filed a complaint in the Regional Trial Court of Makati for âRemoval of Cloud and Delivery of Titleâ against private respondents Emilio Miller, Sr., Rosemarie Olazo, and Manuel Serrana, Jr. Miller, Sr., was petitionerâs business partner in the MS Rice Mill Company, while Olazo and Serrana, Jr. were officials at Manphil Investment Corporation (Manphil). Petitioner therefore prayed that private respondents be ordered to surrender TCT No. 337164 to him and to execute a Deed of Cancellation of Mortgage to be annotated on the back of the title. The RTC of Makati (Branch 150) dismissed petitionerâs complaint and ordered him to pay private respondents P15,000.00 as attorneyâs fees and the costs. On appeal the decision was affirmed. The Court of Appeals held that petitioner and respondent Miller, Sr.âs loan from Manphil was not a partnership obligation but was secured by them in their private capacities with their respective private properties as collateral; and that the funds used by respondent Miller, Sr. to pay did not come from the partnership because at that time, the partnership only had âCash on Bankâ of P2,000.00, âCurrent Assetsâ of P26,807.60, and âFixed Investmentâ of P354,574.68, a total of P381,382.28, which the Court of Appeals noted could not pay off the principal of the P450,000.00 loan. The money came from respondent Miller, Sr.âs wife Felisa. Respondent Miller, Sr. had to advance the amount otherwise he would run the risk of losing his properties which were mortgaged to Manphil together with petitionerâs property covered by TCT No. 337164. Pursuant to the agreement petitioner had with respondent Miller, Sr. after obtaining the loan, if petitioner failed to pay his share (50%) of the semi-annual amortization, respondent Miller, Sr. would advance the necessary amount. Having fully paid the loan respondent Miller, Sr. was subrogated to Manphilâs rights. Consequently, respondent Miller, Sr. could not be compelled to return petitionerâs title until petitioner had fully settled his obligation to respondent Miller, Sr. Petitioner filed this petition contending that under his agreement with respondent Miller, Sr., the latter is entitled to be repaid what the latter has advanced in petitionerâs behalf, and that ownership of petitionerâs land and the bungalow thereon in which petitioner and his family reside should not have âreverted automaticallyâ to respondent Miller, Sr. Petitioner is under a misapprehension. The Court of Appeals did not hold that by virtue of respondent Miller, Sr.âs payment in full of the loan to Manphil, the latter automatically became the owner of petitioners property covered by TCT No. 337164, only that respondent Miller, Sr. succeeded to Manphilâs rights as petitionerâs creditor under Art. 1303 which provides: Art. 1303. Subrogation transfers to the person subrogated the credit with all the rights thereto appertaining, either against the debtor or against third persons, be they guarantors or possessors of mortgages, subject to stipulation in a conventional subrogation. The Court of Appeals erred, however, in holding that respondent Miller, Sr. cannot be compelled to return petitionerâs TCT No. 337164 to him until he ha been repaid what he had advanced in behalf of petitioner. It is disputed that petitionerâs mortgage to Manphil annotated at the back of said title had already been cancelled in 1983, apparently upon payment of the loan. There is therefore no more mortgage to which the property covered by the title is subject and therefore no basis for Miller Sr.âs refusal to return the title to petitioner. WHEREFORE, the decision of the Court of Appeals is REVERSED and private respondent Emilio Miller, Sr. is ORDERED to return petitioner Hilario T. de los Santosâ Transfer Certificate of Title No. 337164 to petitioner without prejudice to his instituting a separate action to collect the latterâs debt. SO ORDERED. Romero, Puno, and Torres, Jr., JJ., concur.
